Staff members in ETV stations and production centers have profited greatly

The secondary advantage of the scholarship program (aided by the
"Workshop Grant-in-Aid program described below) has meanwhile also been

cational institutions to set up training programs and courses in educational
broadcasting on their own. In certain instances, such as Cincinnati, funds
from NAEB scholarships made possible the launching of annual summer work¬
shop programs which promise well for the future.
Workshop Grants-in-Aid
In the last two years the Ford Foundation grant has included funds
specifically earmarked for grants-in-aid to educational institutions holding
ETV workshops, to permit them to bring in outstanding consultants or faculty
members in order to upgrade the caliber of the workshops far above the level
which could have been achieved without such grants • In the two years of
this program, 25 institutions received such grants.
As pointed out in the preceding section, this sort of assistance
(together with scholarships) has enabled some institutions to develop new
programs in this area, or to expand their summer workshop programs by pro¬
